channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: 40 dead in Myanmar sectarian violence
item.description: The death toll from sectarian violence between Buddhists and Muslims in central Myanmar has risen to 40, state media reported Tuesday.

item.title: Sectarian riots spread in Myanmar
item.description: Sectarian riots and fighting spread across central Myanmar.

item.title: When will Cypriot banks re-open?
item.description: Cypriot government orders all banks to remain closed, as CNN's Jim Boulden reports.

item.title: Roadside bomb kills two officials in Iraq
item.description: A roadside bomb exploded Tuesday in northern Iraq, killing the head of the local city council and a member of the provincial council, police said.

item.title: 5 Afghan officers killed as Kerry visits
item.description: Gunmen and suicide bombers attacked police in eastern Afghanistan Tuesday morning, leaving five officers dead, police said.

item.title: Cambodia shuts orphanage over abuse
item.description: An Australian-run orphanage in Cambodia suspected of beating and neglecting the children in its care has been shut down by local authorities.

item.title: U.N. pulls staff from Syria amid violence
item.description: The United Nations is withdrawing some international staff from Syria after shelling near their living quarters in the capital Damascus, a spokesman confirms.

item.title: China's Xi pledges equal African trade
item.description: China's President Xi Jinping's tour of Africa on his first official overseas trip underscores the strategic importance of the continent's oil and mineral resources for the world's second biggest economy, but local leaders are asking whether the relationship has benefited Africa as much as it has China.

item.title: Gay marriage cases head to U.S. court
item.description: The U.S Supreme Court hears arguments on Tuesday and Wednesday about the constitutionality of two laws in the same-sex marriage debate. These are the federal Defense of Marriage Act or DOMA and California's Proposition 8. The high court's decision, expected later this year, could have a profound impact on the definition of families in America.

item.title: Skier dies in avalanche in Canada
item.description: A 38-year-old skier died after being caught in an avalanche in Canada's Glacier National Park, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police said.

item.title: Laser pointer lands man in prison
item.description: A judge in California has sent a strong message to anyone who thinks that pointing lasers at aircraft is just harmless fun 'n' games.

item.title: Golf: Tiger Woods roars back to top spot
item.description: Nearly two-and-a-half years after losing the title, Tiger Woods reclaimed the world No. 1 golf ranking when winning the Arnold Palmer Invitational tournament on Monday.

item.title: Why Cyprus bailout fails to solve debt
item.description: The backslapping and congratulations over the Cyprus bailout deal is still underway, and I realize it is not good form to criticize a deal when the ink has yet to dry on the agreement.

item.title: Why oceans can't wait for rescue
item.description: My grandfather Jacques Cousteau and my father Philippe dedicated their lives to revealing the ocean's wonders and helping us understand our connection to this vast expanse of water. Their work inspired generations and filled people with awe.

item.title: ElBaradei: Egypt's solution 'political'
item.description: Opposition Leader Mohamed ElBaradei says the solution for Egypt's terrible shape is a political one, not a military one.

item.title: Religious tensions persist in Myanmar
item.description: Residents of the city in central Myanmar where clashes between Buddhists and the Muslim minority killed dozens of people last week struggled to resume their daily lives on Monday with a state of emergency still in place.

item.title: Why cigarettes are in the U.S. to stay
item.description: Bob Greene says America's complex relationship with cigarettes and free speech has painted the country into a corner on addressing smoking and its dangers

item.title: Italian judges order murder retrial for Knox, Sollecito
item.description: Italian Supreme Court judges rule Amanda Knox and her ex-boyfriend should stand trial again for the 2007 murder of her former roommate Meredith Kercher in Italy.

item.title: Knox ordered to stand trial again
item.description: Italy's Supreme Court decides whether a re-trial must be held for Amanda Knox. CNN's Ben Wedeman reports.

item.title: Knox's lawyer 'we're ready to fight'
item.description: Amanda Knox's lawyer, Carlo Dalla Vedova, reacts to the Italian Supreme Court ruling that she should stand trial again.

item.title: Opinion: Fascination with 'evil female'
item.description: As Amanda Knox left prison, a free woman for the first time in four years, many were left wondering how someone they've been told was responsible for a bloody murder could walk free.

item.title: Kercher: 'Generous, open, big-hearted'
item.description: Amid the massive global interest in Amanda Knox's appeal against her murder conviction in Italy, it's easy to overlook the victim, British exchange student Meredith Kercher.

item.title: 2011: Knox as pop culture obsession
item.description: Sex. Witch. She-devil.

item.title: Exile Berezovsky's death by 'hanging'
item.description: The autopsy of Boris Berezovsky, a prominent critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin, reports no signs of a violent struggle, British officials say.

item.title: Profile: The rise and fall of an oligarch
item.description: Boris Berezovsky was an oligarch who made a fortune as the Soviet Union collapsed. But by the time he died, he was in financial difficulties.

item.title: How tycoon lost 6 billion dollars
item.description: CNN's Atika Shubert reports on Boris Berezovsky's financial downfall while in exile.

item.title: Exile's death spurs conspiracies
item.description: Friends and allies of Boris Berezovsky passionately insist it isn't a matter of what killed him, but who.

item.title: N. Korea military 'prepares' for strikes
item.description: North Korea says it is placing military units on combat-ready status "to prepare for possible strikes against the U.S. mainland, Hawaii and Guam" and U.S. Pacific bases.

item.title: N. Korea military on 'highest alert'
item.description: North Korea says military units tasked with targeting U.S. bases will be combat ready. CNN's Matthew Chance reports.

item.title: Five things to know: N. Korea threats
item.description: Video propaganda showing the White House and Congress being blown up. Talk of hitting U.S. bases in the Pacific. The renunciation of a 60-year-old armistice that has kept the tenuous peace on the Korean Peninsula.

item.title: U.S., S. Korea sign defense plan
item.description: Col. Cedric Leighton and Gordon Chang discuss the U.S. plan for its involvement in a possible war with North Korea.

item.title: Which N. Korean threats are real?
item.description: North Korea warns U.S. bombing and missile bases are under nuclear threat, as Matthew Chance reports.

item.title: Photos: Kim Jong Un and the military
Tracking huge great white shark
item.description: Here's a view from aboard a fishing boat of what it's like to nab and tag a great white shark for research purposes.

item.title: Becker: Ronaldo the tennis ace?
item.description: Cristiano Ronaldo has the perfect physique for tennis, according to tennis great Boris Becker.

item.title: 'Miniature TV' in your tummy
item.description: PillCam is a ingestible video camera with a transmitter which lets doctors look inside your digestive tract.

item.title: The man behind 'Lara Croft'
item.description: Ian Livingstone is a legend in the fantasy games world. In 1995, he stumbled upon "Lara Croft" and the rest is history.

item.title: Rodman: Kim Jong Un 'my friend'
item.description: Ato Boldon, Politico's Ben Smith and Reihan Salam discuss criticism over Dennis Rodman's trip to North Korea.

item.title: Marcel Desailly's Ghana regret
item.description: French World Cup winning defender Marcel Desailly tells CNN that he would have loved to play for Ghana at least once.

item.title: 'Batman' helps UK police
item.description: A costumed crusader brought in a man wanted for burglary.

item.title: Go inside a sinkhole
item.description: Ever wonder what a sinkhole looks like on the inside? CNN's David Mattingly dives in for a peek in Florida.

item.title: Chemical weapons confusion
item.description: Conflicting reports persist over the use of chemical weapons. There is also growing discord among the opposition.

item.title: Yahoo! to buy teenager's brainchild
item.description: Silicon Valley giant Yahoo is turning to a 17-year-old to boost the company's mobile development by acquiring the teenager's tech start-up in a reported multi-million dollar deal.

item.title: Ditch teachers to fix education
item.description: TED Prize winner Sugata Mitra on how to revolutionize education through self-organized learning.

item.title: Gates' challenge: Build better condom
item.description: Bill Gates is putting out a call to inventors, but he's not looking for software, or the latest high-tech gadget. This time he's in search of a better condom.

item.title: Coral reefs: The pulse of the oceans
item.description: CNN special correspondent Philippe Cousteau explains the impact of climate change on the world's coral reefs.

item.title: Tiger back on top of the world
item.description: More than two years after losing the title, Tiger Woods reclaims the world No. 1 golf ranking. CNN examines how.

item.title: Why Apple wants to track you inside
item.description: Sure, the GPS on your phone or dedicated device can get you from Point A to Point B on the interstate, frustrating "Calibrating ... calibrating ..." moments aside.

item.title: Ford ad causes uproar in India
item.description: Ford says it never approved the racy advertisement which shows scantily clad women tied up in the trunk of a car.

item.title: Long on lyrics, short on rehab
item.description: Is there a stigma about discussing coming clean in a musical genre that many feel has promoted drug use?

item.title: Rapping about drugs
item.description: Is there a stigma about coming clean in a music g

item.title: Becker vs. Mendieta: Keepy-ups
item.description: Tennis legend Boris Becker and ex-Valencia star Gaizka Mendieta face off.

item.title: Watch CNN F.C.'s latest episode
item.description: CNN FC welcomes Ian Wright and Andy Brassell to the show to discuss David Beckham's move to PSG and racism in football.

item.title: China's Michelle Obama?
item.description: Wives of Chinese leaders usually stand in the background, but Peng Liyuan is no ordinary First Lady.

item.title: Would Syria use chemical weapons?
item.description: Few munitions evoke as much fear as chemical weapons, which, unlike nuclear weapons, are relatively inexpensive to develop and stockpile. So does Syria have them and, if so, would it put them to use?

item.title: Should Beckham have moved to PSG?
item.description: Catch all the CNN FC off-field talk, as Pedro Pinto, Ian Wright and others discuss Becks' career as well as racism in football.

item.title: Nadal doing nada: Star unwinds in Mexico
item.description: Don Riddell joins tennis star Rafa Nadal as he unwinds between tournaments in Mexico. Airs in full Thurs 21, 1730 CET

item.title: Plane campaign: Does sexy sell seats?
item.description: Images of bikini-clad women in Thailand posing suggestively in an online ad for a local airline inflamed passions -- both positive and negative -- earlier this year.

item.title: What Mick Jagger is teaching his children
item.description: Ruben Navarrette says being a good parent is about teaching adult children to stand on their own two feet.

item.title: When Princess Diana and Travolta danced
item.description: Sumptuous velvet, delicate sequins, intricate beading: They are dresses fit for a princess -- Princess Diana, that is -- and if you've got a big pocketbook (with a designer label, naturally), they could have been yours.

item.title: Decision-making robots -- here to help
item.description: Despite most humans' land-centric view, Earth is an ocean planet. The global ocean covers more than two-thirds of our planet's surface and makes life as we know it possible: it produces half of the oxygen we breathe, helps regulate our climate and provides the single largest habitat for life on Earth.

item.title: Shark attack caught on tape
item.description: Bryan Plummer talks about capturing amazing video of a great white shark breaking into a diver's cage.

item.title: Google Glass driving fears
item.description: Google Glass, the tech giant's Internet-connected headset, isn't on the market yet. But that hasn't stopped one lawmaker from trying to keep the eyewear off the highways in his state.

item.title: Oceans 'cannot wait' for rescue
item.description: Philippe Cousteau recalls his grandfather's advice and asks how you would like to look at the ocean in 10 years' time -- with regret or awe.

item.title: Quake forces schools outside
item.description: Students spend a school year outside after an earthquake destroyed their schools. CNN's Rafael Romo reports.

item.title: China's first lady turns heads
item.description: Stylish and famous in her own right, CNN's Monita Rajpal looks at Chinese first lady, Peng Liyuan.

item.title: Costa Rica appeals U.S.'s snow win
item.description: It's snow joke: The weather has become the focus of U.S. attempts to qualify for the 2014 World Cup.

item.title: Behind scenes of Musharraf's return
item.description: CNN's Leone Lakhani gives us the back story behind former Pakistan President Pervez Musharraf's return after exile.

item.title: Designer: Obama not a trendsetter
item.description: Oscar de la Renta speaks about why he has not designed something for Michelle Obama. CNN's Lisa Sylvester reports.

item.title: How to live out a video game
item.description: CNN's Patricia Wu and Andrew Stevens try out Hong Kong's latest entertainment, living out a video game.

item.title: Child victims of Iraq War
item.description: It was one of the iconic images of the Iraq war: Ali Abbas, crying in pain on a hospital bed after losing both arms in a US missile attack. Ten years on, Abbas lives in Britain, and is married to his childhood sweetheart.

item.title: What's behind unrest in C.A.R.?
item.description: In just over a day, rebels seized the Central African Republic's capital, forced the president out of the country and declared the nation had "opened a new page in its history."

item.title: Meet China's First Lady
item.description: The wives of Chinese leaders have traditionally lurked in the shadow of their powerful husbands. But not new president Xi Jinping's wife Peng Liyuan.

item.title: How India feeds 1.4 million kids
item.description: In the picturesque temple town of Vrindavan, 10-year-old Maya and her three siblings walk to school every day on an empty stomach. She says her parents can't afford to feed them adequate meals; they eat bread and milk for dinner and nothing for breakfast.

item.title: U.S. county where no one's gay
item.description: Find out what happened when John Sutter visited Franklin Country in the search for an apparently non-existent phenomenon: Same-sex couples.

item.title: How TV show could save lives
item.description: In Ghana, 4,000 women die during pregnancy every year, but a new TV series could be the difference between life and death.

item.title: Things Fall Apart: Achebe and Nigeria
item.description: Chinua Achebe was a genius, but had a troubled relationship with his own country, writes a Nigerian journalist.

item.title: European bailouts 'may backfire'
item.description: Nobel laureate Christopher Pissarides explains why supporters of European integration are disappointed over its "solution" to Cyprus's crisis.

item.title: Same-sex marriage: A potential blockbuster
item.description: The meaning of marriage and the implications of expanding that right to gays and lesbians is now squarely before the U.S. Supreme Court.

item.title: Could lesbian cousin hold sway?
item.description: Chief Justice Roberts' lesbian cousin to attend the Supreme Court hearing on same-sex marriage. CNN's Joe Johns reports.

item.title: Iraq War: Should Bush, Blair be charged?
item.description: It is time for Bush and Blair to be thoroughly investigated for the 'tawdry tale' of the Iraq War, UK lawyer says.

item.title: Photographer shares memories
item.description: Ten years since the U.S. invasion, photojournalist Peter Turnley shares his collection of images from the Iraq War.

item.title: 'I'd rather he was dead than arrested'
item.description: Family and friends focus on one goal: Identify the individual who can help free him in return for money.

item.title: Can you guess where this is?
item.description: Scenes from daily life can be extraordinary -- especially inside this isolated nation. While visitors face restrictions on their movements, photographer Olaf Schuelke offers a rare glimpse inside the "Hermit Kingdom."

item.title: Will planes go 'pay-as-you-weigh'?
item.description: A professor argues heavier folks should pay more for flights. CNN's Nina Dos Santos reports.

item.title: Berezovsky's fall
item.description: Boris Berezovsky was an oligarch who made a fortune as the Soviet Union collapsed. But by the time he died, he was in financial difficulties.

item.title: Cyprus deal
item.description: Cyprus has agreed to a €10 billion ($13B) European Union bailout after a frantic weekend of negotiations with European lenders, preventing the collapse of the island nation's financial sector in a deal that will likely mean huge losses for holders of large deposits at Cyprus' two biggest banks.

item.title: Iraq's victims
item.description: It was one of the iconic images of the Iraq war: Ali Abbas, crying in pain on a hospital bed after losing both arms in a US missile attack. Ten years on, Abbas lives in Britain, and is married to his childhood sweetheart.

item.title: Ocean fears
item.description: Environmental campaigner Philippe Cousteau recalls his grandfather's advice and asks how you would like to look at the ocean in 10 years' time -- with regret or awe.

item.title: China's First Lady
item.description: Wives of Chinese leaders usually stand in the background, but Peng Liyuan is no ordinary First Lady."We've always looked forward to having an elegant First Lady ... now we have one."

item.title: Airlines: Does sex sell?
item.description: Images of bikini-clad women in Thailand posing suggestively in an online ad for a local airline inflamed passions -- both positive and negative -- earlier this year.

item.title: Musharraf's future
item.description: Pervez Musharraf, who wrested power in a bloodless coup in 1999 and lost it nine years later, hopes to lead his party in May elections.

item.title: Oceans on brink of collapse
item.description: As the human footprint has spread, the remaining wildernesses on our planet have retreated. However, dive just a few meters below the ocean surface and you will enter a world where humans very rarely venture.

item.title: Why oceans can't wait
item.description: My grandfather Jacques Cousteau and my father Philippe dedicated their lives to revealing the ocean's wonders and helping us understand our connection to this vast expanse of water. Their work inspired generations and filled people with awe.

item.title: Modeling Earth's ecosystems
item.description: A group of researchers is building a comprehensive model of the Earth's ecosystems to help predict climate change.

item.title: Robots probe ocean depths
item.description: Despite most humans' land-centric view, Earth is an ocean planet. The global ocean covers more than two-thirds of our planet's surface and makes life as we know it possible: it produces half of the oxygen we breathe, helps regulate our climate and provides the single largest habitat for life on Earth.

item.title: Hong Kong: Ivory's Fort Knox
item.description: Hong Kong is fast becoming the Fort Knox of ivory.

item.title: Global warming increases pollen
item.description: With global warming, temperature extremes are becoming a norm -- and that's bad news for allergy sufferers.

item.title: World rejects polar bear plan
item.description: A U.S. plan to give new protection to polar bears was voted down Thursday at an international conference on endangered species.

item.title: Study warns global warming 'epic'
item.description: Global warming has propelled Earth's climate from one of its coldest decades since the last ice age to one of its hottest -- in just one century.

item.title: Philippines taps into geothermal
item.description: Eco Solutions looks at how the Philippines is tapping into its geothermal potential.

item.title: Macau's motorcycles go electric
item.description: A Macau company's love for motorcycles is helping the planet at the same time. CNN's Andrew Stevens reports.

item.title: Environmentalists fill U.S. National Mall
item.description: Marching, dancing and poster-waving environmentalists chanting "Hey, Obama. We don't want no climate drama," packed several blocks on and around Washington's National Mall on Sunday, hoping to spur President Barack Obama to take strong measures against climate change.

item.title: China's glamorous First Lady
item.description: China's new First Lady is poised to impress--and burnish China's image overseas.

item.title: Next stop Tanzania on Xi tour
item.description: CNN's David McKenzie explains why Chinese President Xi Jinping is stopping by Tanzania on his first foreign tour.

item.title: Xi starts foreign tour in Moscow
item.description: China's President Xi Jinping's choice of Moscow as his first foreign capital visit is being seen by analysts as a symbolic move that demonstrates the increasing interdependence of the one-time Cold War foes.

item.title: 2016: China to overtake U.S.
item.description: China is on track for a fourth consecutive decade of rapid growth and will overtake the US as the world's biggest economy in 2016 after accounting for price differences, according to a new report by the OECD.

item.title: China's workforce at a crossroads
item.description: China's extraordinary climb to the world's second largest economy was built on the back of Chinese workers, many of whom left rural farms to migrate for work in coastal factories.

item.title: Chinese bowl sells for $2.2 million
item.description: A rare Chinese bowl bought for about $3 from a yard sale in the U.S. sold for $2.2 million at an auction in New York on Tuesday.

item.title: Pollution 'an economic concern'
item.description: CNN's Philippe Cousteau speaks about Chinese pollution and what can be done to clean up the environmental problems.

item.title: Hollywood dream lost in translation
item.description: When China's most successful homegrown movie went on international release last month, hopes were high that the slapstick comedy, which has drawn comparisons with "The Hangover," would blaze a trail for Chinese-language cinema.
